Award.AbstractNarration: The Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory/Latino Initiative Program (SAO/LIP) offers summer (and potentially year-long) internship opportunities to undergraduate students belonging to minority groups. The students are enrolled at local campuses of the University of Massachusetts (primarily UMass/Lowell). Each intern is paired with a scientific advisor; they work together on a research project in which the student has expressed interest. Students are also paired with a STEM mentor and given training in programming, public speaking, and professional development. Peer mentors are also available for support. The students present the results of their work at national conferences. <br/><br/>The students are exposed to a wide range of outreach activities, including a job fair for people with disabilities and panel discussions on women and minorities in science. One of the most important broader impacts of the project is the year-long exposure not only of the students to SAO researchers but also vice versa.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Since 2018, the Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory-University of Massachusetts/Latino Initiative Program (SAO-UMass/LIP) has sponsored research internships for undergraduate STEM majors at the University of Massachusetts (UMass) in the Urban Massachusetts Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation Programs (UMLSAMP) with support from the National Science Foundation. The primary goal of SAO-UMass/LIP is to prepare local LSAMP students for multiple career pathways in STEM after graduation through an intensive research experience in geophysics and astrophysics on the campus of the Center for Astrophysics | Harvard & Smithsonian (CfA).  The effectiveness of the Program is supported by the fact that all 39 former alumni continue to pursue STEM-related pathways through internships, employment positions, graduate school, and undergraduate majors. In particular, SAO recently hired 3 SAO-UMass/LIP alumni into the following positions: physical scientist, computer engineer, and mechanical engineer, essentially proving that chemistry, computer science, and engineering majors can make outstanding contributions to the field.  Further, by casting a wider net for talent beyond traditional majors at a local, public university, SAO-UMass/LIP has convinced scientists to consider non-traditional majors as research interns.

A unique feature of SAO-UMass/LIP is its commitment to recruit only undergraduates from local campuses to maximize the impact in local communities.  SAO-UMass/LIP accepts applications from students not only majoring in physics and astronomy to facilitate greater participation of underrepresented communities in astrophysics and planetary science, as there are very few UMass UMLSAMP students majoring in physics and astronomy.  This is not surprising if we consider the absence of role models in the field.  However, SAO-UMass/LIP interns stand out from other internship programs because many of them have been able to obtain jobs at the Center supporting critical research projects

With NSF support, the program has become a comprehensive, full-time internship program that attracts students from all four campuses of UMass. Over 50 CfA staff, graduate students, postdoctoral fellows, and scientists annually volunteer to mentor, teach, and instruct SAO-UMass/LIP interns for the rigors of an intensive research projects in astronomy and physics each summer.  Simultaneously, SAO-UMass/LIP has bolstered the population of traditionally underrepresented STEM majors in the SAO Fellowship Program by 16%. 

The interns have changed the environment at CfA providing scientific advisors and staff with invaluable teaching experience and cultural knowledge. They have also expanded the perception of the capabilities of underrepresented minority STEM students in nearby public Universities creating a bi-directional transfer of knowledge interns-SAO scientist. The SAO-UMass/LIP experience has helped transform the cultural stereotypes that prevent many minorities students from pursuing a career in astrophysics.  And SAO-UMass/LIP has had reverberations in the Greater Boston community. SAO-UMass/LIP students are not recruited across the country or the world like other internship programs at the Harvard & Smithsonian Center. The students are often first-generation college students who, in general, must juggle their academic duties with part-time work and do not identify themselves with elite institutions. A majority of SAO-UMass/LIP interns are recruited by their peers who convincingly persuade their classmates or friends that they belong on the Harvard campus.

 

Likewise, SAO-UMass/LIP developed cooperative relationships with local organizations working toward the same goal of preparing local talent to lead STEM innovation.  In particular, the relationship with the satellite campus of the National Autonomous University of Mexico (UNAM) at UMass Boston fosters a network of cooperation between Latino, scholarly, educational, and cultural institutions - and the SAO scientific community. SAO-UMass/LIP has also cultivated long-term relationships with several other organizations in the Greater Boston area including Cambridge Mayor?s Youth Summer Employment Program (MYSEP), ALPFA (Association of Latino Professionals for America), and the Federal Executive Board of Greater Boston, and the Perkins School for the Blind.
